channel.title: U.S. Patent Law Changes, effective Mar. 2013
channel.description:
[url]https://www.edge-online.com/features/great-us-patent-shakeup[/url]
[url='https://www.uspto.gov/aia_implementation/bills-112hr1249enr.pdf']Full Text of the bill, already signed into law by President Obama[/url]
First to File certainly brings a litany of disadvantages to the table for indie developers, but also cuts down on junk lawsuits. Good things and bad things in this bill. Anyone else ever hear of this? Why didn't it hit the media like a brick like SOPA/PIPA did?

item.title: U.S. Patent Law Changes, effective Mar. 2013
item.dc:creator: geekofalltrades
item.description:
OrderOfDagon:

How is it opposite - I’m not arguing, I’m actually intrigued?

By far the best definition I’ve heard for irony is “a juxtaposition of the expected and the unexpected.”

In ironic wordplay, the irony arises because you expect the words to mean one thing, when they can actually be interpreted to mean exactly the opposite. It’s difficult for me to think of a concrete example; situational irony is so much more common. Eg, a fire station burning down is ironic in the extreme, or a person who’s scared of flying finally getting on a plane for the first time only to have the plane crash and kill them.

You also get people doing something ironically; eg, I could call somebody a nigger, and people who know me would know that I’m doing it ironically, because it’s the opposite of the way anyone would expect me to behave. Again, you get expected clashing with opposite and unexpected.

Interpreting “Jesus Christ, you’re delusional” as a addressing Jesus Christ isn’t really ironic, then; it’s just taking it out of context. It’s no more ironic than interpreting “fuck me” as a request when the person speaking actually meant it as a mildly self-deriding profanity.

Of course, interpretation of irony is one of those things that people will argue all day. For example, you could argue that “Jesus Christ, you’re delusional” would be extremely ironic if it were being said by one of Jesus’ disciples, because you could interpret it as them calling Jesus delusional, which is clearly the opposite of the way they actually viewed Jesus. color=black

Read full topic

item.title: U.S. Patent Law Changes, effective Mar. 2013
item.dc:creator: geekofalltrades
item.description:
OrderOfDagon:

The use[/SIZE] of words[/SIZE] expressing something other than their literal intention[/SIZE].

Actually, irony in this context would be more accurately described as “the use of words expressing something opposite to their literal intention.” But that’s a pretentious argument that I don’t particularly feel like having right now.

Read full topic

item.title: U.S. Patent Law Changes, effective Mar. 2013
item.dc:creator: OrderOfDagon
item.description:
The use[/SIZE] of words[/SIZE] expressing something other than their literal intention[/SIZE].

It’s ironic to the audience concerned. (i.e. Me)

Usually when you watch a play or a film, the irony is not noticed by the characters, but to the audience who has seen the rising actions that make it ironic to being with; You don’t know what irony is.

Kairouseki:

Here’s a thought. You’re retarded .

You’re missing the “contention” part.

item.title: U.S. Patent Law Changes, effective Mar. 2013
item.dc:creator: OrderOfDagon
item.description:
bur:

“jesus christ” in the context i used it in is a figure of speech, it holds no religious significance.

That’s why it’s ironic.
If you read it literally and convergent, without applying the fore-knowledge of the slang or figure of speech, it has an entirely new meaning.
“Jesus Christ, you’re delusional.”
If you read it differently then intended, you change the the figure of speech “Jesus Christ” to a noun -which it initially is- forming the phrase into something I hear annoying, pseudo atheists say a lot.
Thus irony.
Irony: The use of words expressing something other than their literal intention.

I never said I go around saying that – no need to call me a douche.

Read full topic
item.source: U.S. Patent Law Changes, effective Mar. 2013

item.description:
no, not subjective

you’re just a flaming idiot

“jesus christ” in the context i used it in is a figure of speech, it holds no religious significance, and, in fact, means nothing at all
it’s nothing more than an outcry of surprise or shock

so saying that it was ironic is just douchy (im an atheist too)

also irony is not subjective

item.title: U.S. Patent Law Changes, effective Mar. 2013
item.dc:creator: gibbelin
item.description:
I’m not sure what the implications of this change are (but I plan on looking into it) but I do know that they really need to do away with the majority of software patents. The idea of patents is to protect innovators, and the current law does the opposite.

Certain types of software patents are tantamount to patenting mathematics (there are only so many ways to accomplish a goal with binary) and patent trolls crush innovation by suing the pants of thousands of hapless startups who thought they’d made something new. It’s bullshit.

Read full topic
item.source: U.S. Patent Law Changes, effective Mar. 2013
